G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 218, § 19 because the matter in controversy does not exceed $50,000, and the cause of action arose in the city of Somerville, Massachusetts.

M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 186, § 14, Massachusetts law provides that a landlord shall not interfere with a tenant’s legal right to quiet enjoyment of the leased premises, and any such interference constitutes a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994) established the expectation that landlords must take appropriate steps to address tenant complaints regarding disruptions that interfere with quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court expressly holds that a landlord’s failure to take available measures in response to ongoing unlawful conduct that seriously interferes with tenants’ use of the premises can constitute a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. The opinion emphasizes that the housing authority may be liable if, despite tenant complaints, it “stood idle” and failed to take relatively easy steps to address the disruptive presence of drug dealers in common areas. This directly aligns with the proposition that landlords must take appropriate steps to address tenant complaints about disruptions interfering with quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “If the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … Thus, the record suggests that the defendant stood idle, despite continued requests and complaints by the tenants regarding the drug activity on the rented premises.”

Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg'l V.raw_text: Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg'l Voc-Tech Sch. Dist., 461 Mass. 366, 370 (2012)
Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg'l V.proposition: Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg'l Voc-Tech Sch. Dist., 461 Mass. 366, 370 (2012) affirmed landlords’ obligations under Massachusetts lease law.
Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg'l V.case_name: Town of Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Regional Vocational Technical High School District
Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg'l V.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with the apportionment of public school funding obligations among member municipalities in a regional school district under the Massachusetts Education Reform Act. It concerns statutory interpretation, implied repeal, preemption, and municipal standing to assert constitutional claims, not landlord–tenant or lease law. Nothing in the decision addresses or affirms landlords’ obligations under Massachusetts lease law, so the proposition mischaracterizes the case’s subject matter and holding.
Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg'l V.relevant_excerpt: "We now consider whether the public school funding obligations imposed on the member municipalities by the Education Reform Act supersede the funding provisions of an agreement among the member municipalities entered into pursuant to St. 1971, c. 428, which authorized the formation of the school district. We also consider whether the member municipalities, as political subdivisions of the Commonwealth, have standing to challenge the constitutionality of the Education Reform Act."

A. John Cohen Ins. Agency, Inc. v. Massa.raw_text: A. John Cohen Ins. Agency, Inc. v. Massachusetts Insurers Insolvency Fund, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 548 (2000)
A. John Cohen Ins. Agency, Inc. v. Massa.proposition: A. John Cohen Ins. Agency, Inc. v. Massachusetts Insurers Insolvency Fund, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 548 (2000) explains how lease interpretations are to be construed under state law.
A. John Cohen Ins. Agency, Inc. v. Massa.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a motion to suppress evidence following a traffic stop, focusing on probable cause, drug paraphernalia, and warrantless seizure/search under the Fourth Amendment and Massachusetts law. It does not address the interpretation or construction of leases or any other contract-interpretation doctrines. Therefore, it cannot be used as authority for how lease interpretations are to be construed under state law.
A. John Cohen Ins. Agency, Inc. v. Massa.relevant_excerpt: The definition of “drug paraphernalia” in c. 94C, § 1, is not without its interpretive difficulties. It is not entirely clear, for example, whether the inclusion of “bongs” within the list of “objects used, primarily intended for use or designed for use in . . . inhaling [a controlled substance]” is alone sufficient to constitute bongs as “drug paraphernalia,” or whether, as the defendant argues, the Commonwealth must also... establish that the object is “primarily intended or designed for use in . . . inhaling or otherwise introducing into the human body a controlled substance.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Statutory damages and attorneys’ fees for violation of quiet enjoyment were upheld in Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion makes clear that while the landlord was held liable under the quiet enjoyment statute (G.L. c. 186, § 14) so as to justify an award of attorneys’ fees, the court vacated the $10,000 damages verdict on the quiet enjoyment count as duplicative. Thus, statutory attorneys’ fees under § 14 were upheld, but statutory damages for violation of quiet enjoyment were not; the tenant ultimately did not retain a damages award on that count. The proposition overstates what was upheld in Simon v. Solomon.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “In sum, taking into account the relationships among the three counts of Solomon’s claim, and the instructions that accompanied their submission to the jury, we find no acceptable basis for the verdict awarding $10,000 to Solomon for interference with quiet enjoyment. … Accordingly, we vacate it. … After trial, the judge assessed attorneys’ fees of slightly more than $40,000 for Solomon, based on the fee provision of G. L. c. 186, § 14. … Therefore, Solomon’s claim for emotional distress was within the scope of § 14, and was properly considered in the determination of attorneys’ fees.”

Bosse v. O'Connell, 69 Mass. App. Ct. 1.raw_text: Bosse v. O'Connell, 69 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (2007)
Bosse v. O'Connell, 69 Mass. App. Ct. 1.proposition: Bosse v. O'Connell, 69 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (2007) underscores the importance of the covenant and the harm that can arise from its breach.
Bosse v. O'Connell, 69 Mass. App. Ct. 1.case_name: Hingham Mutual Fire Insurance v. Smith
Bosse v. O'Connell, 69 Mass. App. Ct. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion is an insurance coverage decision focused on policy exclusions for injuries arising out of sexual molestation. It does not discuss any covenant (such as the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, a covenant in a lease, or any other contractual covenant), nor does it analyze harms from the breach of a covenant as a doctrinal matter. The proposition about underscoring the importance of a covenant and harm from its breach is therefore inapposite to the issues and holding of this case.
Bosse v. O'Connell, 69 Mass. App. Ct. 1.relevant_excerpt: "We agree with the motion judge that there is no coverage under the personal liability section (Coverage L) of the homeowner’s policy if only because the injuries alleged by the Smiths ‘arise[] out of . . . the actual, alleged or threatened sexual molestation of a person’ and thus do not constitute ‘bodily injur[y]’ as defined by the policy... It is the source from which the plaintiff[s’] personal injury originates rather than the specific theories of liability alleged... which determines the insurer’s duty to defend."
